title: How to score good marks for English literature - Quora

response.answer_text: Scoring good marks in English Literature demands a bit of hard as well as smart work. The hard work is before the examination. You should have a sound understanding of all the topics that are scheduled for your upcoming examination. I will list down some techniques which I followed to fetch great marks. For poems — be clear about the author, his intention of writing the poem and on what theme is the poem based. It really helps to know certain technicalities like the metre on which the poem runs and what are the figure of speech used in it. Whatever the question a clever mention of these things will definitely impress your teacher.Plays and novels are almost same except that in plays you have to remember which event occurred in which act of the play. Be very thorough about this.mentioning the act number and the scene number with all the characters present in the particular scene is always a good bet even if you don't know a lot about the play. Secondly again remembering the age to which the author belongs and the background in which the play/novel was written is crucial.There may be other topics like Literary Criticism or History of English Literature or Language. These are mostly fact based topics and you need to prepare notes on each and every chapter because they help form a strong foundation of the subject for you. Please do not ignore these especially History of English Literature because it is like the subject Mathematics of our school days. The more you try to escape it's clutches the more tightly it will grasp back at you with its claws! Don't be scared. English is a subject to be enjoyed and loved. The more you love it the better it will serve you in the future.All the best!

Start by reading the assignments listed in your course calendar. Actually read them. Don't put the anthology under your pillow and hope to absorb the works by osmosis.  While you are reading them, take a pencil and mark anything that catches your eye, like words you are unfamiliar with, interesting phrasing, ideas that don't seem to fit with the rest of the theme or style, etc.  If the class is discussion based, wade on in. Take some chances with your interpretations. Back the argument with evidence from the work itself. Maybe do a little research on the context in which the work is written. For example, if you are studying "Red Badge of Courage" having some context for the American Civil War is helpful. If you are studying Faulkner, some knowledge of the South after the Civil War makes all the difference.  Make sure that when you write the papers, you follow the instructions and don't take your sources from study sites like Sparknotes. Use the school's databases to find legitimate critics who have discussed the work, author, or context of the piece. Work on it from the day it is assigned. It takes time to read the work and then find the research, so procrastination is the enemy here. Write a couple of drafts. Check you that you actually writing analysis and not a summary. Make sure you have proper quotes, paraphrases, and summaries, and that they are properly cited. Show your work in other words. Then turn it in on time. These habits should produce excellent marks in literature, or any other course you might take. As a bonus, you might actually learn something in addition to ticking off a grade. But if grades are what you seek, just do your work, follow the instructions on the assignment sheet, syllabus, and course outline, don't phone in your efforts, and be on time.

I don’t know what exam you’re doing, but I’m going to assume it’s either an A Level or an O Level and structure my answer accordingly. Make sure you go through the assigned texts thoroughly. Shmoop won’t give you an A, nor will skimming through your prose/poems and googling the summaries/cribbing off your friends. Perhaps it might sound inconvenient, but you shouldn’t be doing a subject unless you’re willing to put in the effort required.Read similar books or plays — ones that share thematic structures or plot lines. Bringing your background reading up in your answer is a great way of coercing your examiner to grant you more marks.Related to the point above — read texts by the same author/poet. You need to know what their writing styles are and what themes they favour. You also need to know a little about what’re like as people, as that may have a significant influence on the works that they produce.Make sure you conduct some research into the period in which each piece was written and find some way of dropping this info in your answer — usually in support of some literary idea you are putting forward.Practice writing answers. No two words about it — this is vital. There’s no way I would have got over an A if I hadn’t kept working on my answers.Once you notice a marked improvement in your answers, time them. You’ll have a time limit at your exam and you don’t want this to throw you.All in all, literature exams tend to be easier than language ones (at least in my opinion), but you’ve got to put in the extra effort. Good luck!

First of all improve your grammar. Board exams are generally lengthy and torturous, even good students tend to make a lot of grammatical mistakes making the answer unintelligible and thus resulting in reduced marks..Secondly, read the chapter first every time you study. Make character sketches, solve back exercises and try to position yourself as the protagonist. Might sound bizarre but this one practice made my answering ability improve from nil to a hundred..I won't recommend this but I watched sitcoms and movies to improve my prompt answering skill and it really reflected my performance when it came to writing. It's a distraction? I had PCM with comp. science. I got 93.25% aggregate and 95/100 in English. These things don't really effect your studies until you have everything balanced.. DONT WRITE A LOT TO CONFUSE. Board examiners are pretty well versed and extra long answers just reflect the nervousness and incapability of the student to answer a question. Keep your answer short, compact and rich in content..Last but not the least, jump out of your comfort zone. Read novels, poetry and non-fiction books to get that required flow in English Language. Don't just care about your marks, they're temporary. Try to learn English to better yourself and your personality after all it's just an exam that won't decide your future.Kudos and all the best for your exams :)

I'm giving this answer for bachelors and masters students, and not for boards students. Read the text first, i.e. prose poetry play fiction etc, whatever it is….you should read it first. Then read a few factual details about the writer, like where was he from, what was the age or time period he wrote in, influences on the writer, his philosophy of life, socio-politico-economic conditions of that age. Then just go through the other works written by the writer. Just try to know a one para summary of his or her works. That much is enough. Now read a few research papers on the work that is in your syllabus. Highlight a few important lines said by the critics. You can use them to quote in your answers. And yes, while reading the text, do the same….select a few quotes which you can use in your answers. You can also go for a comparative analysis if you're a good reader. Don't mug up. Just mug up the quotes, as they fetch good marks. Try to inculcate a habit of writing essay type questions. Write it on your own after doing the base work.

What I can say is that studying English Literature  necessitates a comparatively good command of the English Language, on top of a keen ability to think, interpret, predict, and empathise, and of course, to write expressively. Frankly, literature to me entails three important things: Perspectives and skills of literary criticism, plus the discipline of using special vocabulary and style of analysis;Personal interpretations and expressions;Special voice in speaking and writing; So from the standpoint of literary pursuits, there are no short cuts in the improvement process. It's has to be a lifestyle! My advice: Read, read, and read widely and deeply;Read alone;Read in print if possible;Make marginal annotations;Take notes and make notes;Read for clarity;Read a aloud;Write, write, and write profusely;Constant rewriting, revision and restructuring come with the territory;Keep a daily journal of your reading and writing experiences;[20160406_Study English Literature]

The following lines may help you to score good marks. 1. Be clear with the characters of all stories. The role of a character in every context must be clear. 2. You must know all the grammatical elements like similes,  metaphors etc. 3. You must be prepared for justification o titles of all chapters. 4. You must be able to give your critical comments on sequences and events of stories 5. Write quality answers i.e. use good vocabulary, write to the point whatever is necessary. For this you must also have an idea of the scheme of evaluation. 6. Read model answers in some good books preferably morning star or goyal publications. All the best!

Know all your chapters. Like really really well. But you could focus less on the chapters asked last year, as they don't usually repeat.  That's a first. Short stories are easy to score. Poems require you to really understand things on a metaphorical level. Focus on that and try reading between the lines. There can be two things a poet tries to say through a single line. Take note. Learn up the poet and author names well and also character sketches for short stories. Keep your answers descriptive and elaborate but also don't add unnecessary details as it won't get you extra marks.  Coming to Shakespeare, know important bits from each act like where the scene is taking place, who's speaking to whom about what, reference to context, etc. Also, there may be biblical allusions,alliterations and so on. Do those well.  Avoid attempting extra questions and aim to write only what is needed, but perfectly. Don't use incorrect grammar. Do the 20 mark summary only if you're very sure. All the best! :)

Scoring good marks in english board exam is actually quite easy. All you need to do is practice and read.  Correct grammar is a must. In the time allotted for reading the question paper go through the reading comprehension twice. First a quick read, then reading according to the questions asked. This will save a lot of time later. Once writing time starts, finish off writing the answers to the section A asap. Then preceed to literature section, and then finally the writing section.  Time should be properly divided bwtween all the sections. In the following manner B > C > A.For your literature section read all ypur poems and chapters thoroughly. Memorize the names of all the poems and their poet, because thats generally the first question in RTCs.For the writing section, remember all the formats. Write neatly. Leave proper space between and after every answer.

What Marcia said. One thing I've discovered as a tutor that I want to emphasize.  Read the instructions. Break them down so you understand each part of them. If you are in any doubt at all that you have misunderstood, ask your teacher for clarification and keep on asking until you do understand. Students of English often try get carried away with their own ideas and want to show them off for the teacher. That's fine but only if you follow the instructions too. Believe it or not, the teacher assigns essays and gives instructions in order to help you master a skill, so going your own way while writing could leave you high and dry in the marks department.

Read. A lot. Read classic literature, read genre lit like science fiction and mystery, read non-fiction, read poetry, read news articles, read product labels. The best way to become better at English literature is by immersing yourself in it. And don’t just skim it, really try to understand it and the context in which it was written. Don’t be afraid to look up words or phrases you don’t understand. It can be difficult but the more you work at it, the easier it gets. If you can, find a group of like-minded English lit nerds you can talk with about what you’re reading.

Do a little research on the background for the concerned novel or poem or topic of discussion. Eg. if you are reading a novel, read about the social, religious and political conditions going on in that time period, the issues of race or gender,etc also read critical analysis and essays regarding the same . Also read detailed analysis for your concerned topics. Then while writing an answer or an assignment quote critics and phrases  you found interesting.

English literature is a subject which solely focuses on your language skills, how well you can understand various works of different genres by multiple authors.  The best way to go about is to read, more then what your course or school wants you to, not just novels but all kinds of works, articles, blogs etc. Not only will they help you gain knowledge, with a conscious approach, you will be able to see the difference between how the literary aspects change from work to work and from author to author.  Also, always pay attention in what is being taught in class, because for understanding the technical aspects, your teacher is the only guidebook you will have.

There’s no secret on scoring high on a English literature class. You just have to be familiar with each of the literary movements, that is from Ancient up to post-modernism. Also, you have to be aware of the theme, among all the elements that constitutes every literary piece. Being a fan of many different literary figures and their style and/or approach is a requirement as well.

Read the books. Not the summaries. Learn about the authors and the influences on their lives like wars and social movements and inventions. Do it yourself instead of being like all the Quorans who ask “what happens in this book and show examples of the symbolism of the thingie I obviously don' t understand”.

Scoring good marks in English Literature is tough but not impossible. Have a focus. Refer to previous years' question paper. Without theory and interpretation, your answers will be incomplete. So along with the text, know the theory related to it. Find out the possible interpretations. Your answers should be top notch and be differentiated from the answers of others. Try to understand the question. Don't write stories. Answer to the question.

Have a new perspective on the content with an argument (thesis) that is both creative and analytical. Don’t simply recapitulate existing arguments on the text. This doesn’t contribute anything new to the ongoing academic discussions about the literature. That is, you want to have a fresh, original idea that no one has really considered before, which is how you expand on the overall understanding of a text.

Reading and analysing texts is the only way to understand literature. Read as much as you can and by this i don’t mean only novels and literature. You should have knowledge of everything under the sky. History of English literature and the texts along with their authors should be on your tips. Although using guides is not recommended you can use one for last minute preparation but only the good ones just to get a background check. All the best!

Read, read, read and then read some more. This is the best way to expand your knowledge, your vocabulary and your world view. And write as often as you can find the time. Expressing oneself on paper is fulfilling and a wonderful way to enrich one’s mind. The personal benefits of appreciating literary works are more important than the grades received.
